conversation.content: Did you just [laugh hard] trip over your own cape getting on the bus?

Listen, superhero costumes and public transit were not designed to coexist peacefully. The cape got caught in the door, then wrapped around some lady's stroller, and I basically clotheslined myself trying to untangle it— peak dignity right there.
You're going to, um, Comic-Con dressed as— I mean, who even [furious] is that supposed to be, honestly?

Captain Catastrophe! He's my own creation— his superpower is that everything he touches breaks in comedically inconvenient ways. I figured if I'm gonna embarrass myself at these things anyway, might as well lean into it.
That's, er, actually brilliant— you know, in a sort of weird way.

Right? Last year I went as Superman and spent the whole time apologizing for not being buff enough. This year when kids ask for photos, I just knock something over and yell "Captain Catastrophe strikes again!" Way less pressure.
Your cape is [happy] backwards by the way.
Oh for the love of— see, this is exactly what I'm talking about! Even my costume is in character. Though between you and me, I put it on backwards on purpose because it looks funnier when I run.
You're [delighted] planning to run in that thing?

There's a costume race at noon! Basically, fifty nerds sprinting, well, in full cosplay— last year Spider-Man, uh, lost his mask mid-race and just kept going with his regular face showing, absolutely killed the mystique.
How do you even find out about these things?

My thirteen-year-old niece thinks I'm the coolest uncle ever, which is hilarious because I'm literally just desperate for her approval. She sends me Instagram posts and I show up places dressed like an idiot— it's a beautiful system.
That's, hmm, surprisingly wholesome— I guess, for someone wearing, er, a neon orange cape.

The orange was actually, you know, a printing error— supposed to be red, but honestly, the print shop messed up and I thought, hey, Captain Catastrophe would definitely, um, order the wrong color cape.
You're really, like, committed to this bit, aren't you? I mean, that's actually, sort of, impressive dedication.
Oh you have no idea— I've got business cards that, er, self-destruct when you touch them, literally just dissolve into glitter, and honestly, the mess is, well, absolutely worth people's reactions.
Wait, you made business cards that— actually, [trailing off] that's kind of genius...

The glitter is biodegradable! Had to special order it from some eco-craft website after the convention center banned me from using regular glitter— apparently "glitter bombing" paying customers is frowned upon, who knew?
They banned you?

Just from using glitter! I can still attend, thankfully, though they, um, [long pause] specifically mentioned no confetti cannons either, which honestly feels targeted because that was, you know, ONE time and the sprinklers barely went off.
